source.title: Source
source.description:
Main source for information on the controller specifications
Ideally either a link to a manual on the Internet Archive or to an archived webpage on the Wayback Machine

ControllerDefinition.title: Controller
ControllerDefinition.description:
Controller Definition
Note: Any consideration related to buttons and their categorization should be related to the default mapping of said buttons

scroll_wheel.title: Scroll Wheel
scroll_wheel.description: Whether or not the controller has a scroll wheel

menu_buttons.title: Menu Buttons
menu_buttons.description:
Buttons traditionally mapped to open an in-game menu
e.g.: Start, Select

system_buttons.title: System Buttons
system_buttons.description:
Buttons traditionally mapped to open a system menu or perform an OS-level operation
e.g.: Share, Home

other_buttons.title: Other Buttons
other_buttons.description:
Buttons which do not perform any software-level or OS-level operation on the console or PC they are connected to, and are not recognized as buttons by the software or OS
e.g.: Power, Sync, Turbo, Profile

gyroscope.title: Gyroscope
gyroscope.description: Whether or not the controller has an integrated gyroscope

accelerometer.title: Accelerometer
accelerometer.description: Whether or not the controller has an integrated accelerometer

macro.title: Macro
macro.description:
Indicates if the buttons of the controller can be mapped to perform a sequence of and/or simultaneous standard button presses automatically
Not to be confused with Turbo
Includes the simultaneous pressing of directional buttons

turbo.title: Turbo
turbo.description:
Indicates if the buttons of the controller can be mapped to simulate the frequent and periodic pressing and unpressing of said button when held
Not to be confued with Macro

ir_reciever.title: Infrared Receiver
ir_reciever.description: Whether or not the controller has an integrated Infrared Receiver

extension_ports.title: Extension Ports
extension_ports.description: Number of additional data ports present on the controller, excluding any cable port used for connecting or charging the device, or the Headset Port

headset_port.title: Headset Port
headset_port.description: Whether or not the controller has an integrated Jack headphone port

speaker.title: Speaker
speaker.description: Whether or not the controller has an integrated speaker

microphone.title: Microphone
microphone.description: Whether or not the controller has an integrated microphone

bluetooth.title: Bluetooth
bluetooth.description: Whether or not the controller is capable to connect wirerlessly to a device via Bluetooth

2_4ghz.title: 2.4GHz
2_4ghz.description: Whether or not the controller is capable to connect wirerlessly to a device via a 2.4GHz connection, including if said connection requires an additional dongle provided with the controller

rumble.title: Rumble
rumble.description:
Type of rumble functionnality offered by the controller, if it applies.
- standard: Refers to traditional rumble motors found in the Nintendo GameCube controller for instance
- enhanced: Refers to any kind of haptic feedback implemented other than the former, as seen for instance in the Nintendo Switch Joy-Con or the Sony Dualsense

pc_xinput.title: XInput compatibility
pc_xinput.description: Whether or not the controller can be recognized by Windows and Windows games as an XInput controller with no additional drivers or adapters, and as such behave as an Xbox 360 controller would

pc_steaminput.title: Steam Input compatibility
pc_steaminput.description: Whether or not the controller can be recognized by Steam on Windows and Linux with no additional drivers or adapters, and translate the controller inputs to XInput via Steam Input

native_consoles.title: Native Consoles
native_consoles.description:
Lists the consoles on which the controller can be used without the use of an adapter, for most games.
In the case of the PS5, applies if the controller is recognized by the PS4 compatibility layer implemented in Street Fighter 6 and other fighting games as well.

ActionButton.title: Action Button
ActionButton.description:
Button traditionally mapped to performing an action in video games (e.g. Jump, Punch, Kick, Interact…)
Can be Analog or Digital
e.g.: A, B, X, Y, LT, LB, RT, RB

AnalogStick.title: Analog Stick
AnalogStick.description:
Control stick offering fine-tuned control beyond the traditional 8 directions of a directional pad
e.g. The Left and Right stick of the Sony Dualsense

DigitalStick.title: Digital Stick
DigitalStick.description:
Control stick only capable of transmitting up to 8 discrete inputs
e.g. The stick of a Street Fighter II Arcade Cabinet

Cable.title: Cable
Cable.description: Cable or cable port allowing for a connection between a console or PC and the controller

modifier_buttons.title: Modifier Button
modifier_buttons.description: Number of modifier buttons whose sole purpose is to change the value of the analog output value of a button press or analog stick axis

DigitalToAnalogConversion.title: Digital-to-Analog Conversion
DigitalToAnalogConversion.description:
Digital-to-analog conversion capabilities the controller may be able to perform
- 8_way: The device is only capable of emulating the 8 extreme cardinal inputs for said analog stick
- button: The device is only capable of emulating the full press of said button
- precision: The exact output of said button or analog stick axis can be controlled and fine-tuned either via hard mapping in the controller’s firmware, or using modifier buttons

DirectionalButton.title: Directional Button Set
DirectionalButton.description: Set of Individual Buttons which, together, can transmit direction-based inputs to a game similar to a Digital Stick

hardware.title: Hardware SOCD Prevention
hardware.description: Whether or not there is a hardware-based solution which may physically prevent two Simultaneously Opposite Cardinal Direction to be pressed at the same time, e.g. a D-Pad’s pivot

SocdPrevention.title: SOCD Prevention
SocdPrevention.description: Hardware or software-based solutions which may prevent sending two Simultaneously Opposite Cardinal Direction inputs to the console or PC

SoftwareSOCD.title: Software SOCD Prevention
SoftwareSOCD.description:
List of software-based solutions offered by the controller’s firmware which may prevent sending two Simultaneously Opposite Cardinal Direction inputs to the console or PC, if any
- neutral: Pressing Left+Right or Up+Down cancels the input and sends a Neutral position to the console or PC
- last_input: Pressing Left+Right or Up+Down sends the last pressed direction to the console or PC
- first_input: Pressing Left+Right or Up+Down will ignore the new direction being sent and sends the first pressed direction to the console or PC
- up: (Only for Up+Down) Pressing Up+Down always sends Up to to the console or PC
- disable: Software SOCD Prevention can be disabled, leading to both Left & Right inputs or Up & Down inputs being sent to the console or PC

Trackpad.title: Trackpad
Trackpad.description: Tactile sensor commonly found on laptops to emulate a mouse

image.title: Image
image.description:
Name of a PNG image showing the mentionned variant
The image must be placed in the same folder as this config file
Note: At least one of the variants must use the default `image.png` file

Variant.title: Variant
Variant.description:
A different way to use the controller than the one seen on the base image.png file, usually through the use of additional accessories which may attach to the controller
May be omitted if the controller only has one variant
Note: Must include a name for the base variant
